questions.text: Match the following epilepsy syndromes with their characteristic EEG findings:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Janz syndrome refers to Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy and is characterised by generalised 4 to 5­ Hz polyspike and slow-­ wave discharges.
  • West syndrome shows a typical EEG picture called Hypsarrhythmia is a high-­ voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes.
  • Lennox-­ Gastaut syndrome is characterised by 1 to 2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep (also called generalised paroxysmal fast activity or GPFA), and a slow background in wakefulness.
  • Rolandic epilepsy, another name for benign childhood epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes (BECTS). EEG shows typical wide-­ based centrotemporal spikes that are markedly increased in frequency during drowsiness and sleep.

Key Takeaways:

choices.text: Total duration of ATT is 12 months
Basal cistern exudates are the radiological hallmark
No role of steroids in the therapy

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding tubercular meningitis in a child, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Steroids are beneficial in tuberular meningitis as they help to reduce inflammation, cerebral oedema, and risk of complications such as raised ICP and infarcts.

Tubercular meningitis:

  • Usually occurs secondary to a primary focus (e.g., pulmonary, gastrointestinal) with hematogenous spread leading to a Rich focus (meningeal lesion) and subsequent spread to the CSF.

Risk factors:

  • Protein-energy malnutrition
  • Younger age
  • Close contact with a TB case
  • HIV infection or other immunosuppression
  • Inadequate or no BCG vaccination
  • Previous or untreated pulmonary TB

Clinical features:

  • The first or prodromal phase of the illness, which lasts 1-4 weeks, is characterised by nonspecific irregular fever, anorexia, irritability and occasional vomiting.
  • Stage 2 has neurological manifestations like seizures, focal deficits and meningeal signs.
  • Stage 3 is one of coma and sequelae.

Diagnosis:

  • CSF findings:
    • Elevated opening pressure
    • Lymphocytic predominance with up to 500 cells per mm’
    • Increased protein levels
    • Low sugar level (about half the concomitant blood sugar level)
    • Low CSF chloride level and elevated ADA levels
    • If CSF is left to stand still, a fine clot resembling a pellicle or cobweb may form
  • Neuroimaging often shows hydrocephalus and basal exudates with signs of cerebral oedema or early focal ischemia. (Option C ruled out)
  • Culture is the gold standard for diagnosing tuberculous meningitis.

Treatment:

  • Anti-tubercular therapy for tubercular meningitis is given for 9-12 months, comprising an intensive phase of 3 months and a consolidation phase of 6-9 months (Option B ruled out).
  • Intravenous dexamethasone is recommended for 8-12 weeks to reduce inflammation-related complications, and then transitioning to oral steroids for 6-8 weeks to help prevent long-term sequelae in most children.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with an increased risk of future epilepsy in a child with febrile seizures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Late age of onset is not a risk factor for future epilepsy, while younger age at onset is more often associated with febrile seizure recurrence, but not with epilepsy risk.

  • Although approximately 15% of children with epilepsy have had febrile seizures, only 5% (range 1-33%, dependent on risk factors) of children who experience febrile seizures proceed to develop epilepsy later in life.
  • There are several predictors of epilepsy after febrile seizures.

choices.text: Presence of Cushing's triad with papilledema

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is admitted with signs of raised intracranial pressure, including papilledema on fundus examination. His GCS is 9/15, and he has Cushing's triad. He has been started on IV mannitol, and neuroimaging is performed. Which of the following findings would indicate the need to add dexamethasone to his management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Dexamethasone is indicated in cases of raised intracranial pressure (ICP) due to intracranial space-occupying lesions (ICSOLs)like cysts, abscesses and tumours.
  • Glucocorticoids reduce vasogenic oedema around the lesion by decreasing capillary permeability and stabilising the blood-brain barrier.
  • This results in reduced mass effect and ICP, improving symptoms and buying time until definitive treatment (surgery/ATT/antibiotics).

Explanation of other options:

Presence of Cushing's triad with papilledema (Option A): This indicates raised ICP, but dexamethasone is not routinely indicated unless the cause is an ICSOL or inflammatory lesion.
For raised ICP from trauma, hydrocephalus, or idiopathic intracranial hypertension, steroids have no proven benefit and may worsen outcomes.

History of head trauma (Option B): Steroids are avoided in traumatic brain injury because they can worsen outcomes by increasing the risk of hyperglycemia, gastrointestinal bleeding, immunosuppression, and infection.

Fall in GCS below 8 (Option D): GCS<8 indicates severe brain injury, requires intubation and aggressive ICP management, including head elevation, sedation, osmotic therapy (mannitol or hypertonic saline), and treatment of the underlying cause; however, steroids are not indicated.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are X-linked dominant disorders except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Asperger syndrome is not inherited in an X-linked dominant or recessive manner, while all other conditions mentioned have an X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance.

  • Asperger syndrome does not follow a defined single-gene inheritance pattern; it is considered multifactorial, resulting from a combination of genetic predisposition and environmental factors, and is not inherited in an X-linked dominant or recessive manner.
  • Asperger syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder within the family of autism spectrum disorders.
  • It is characterised by impaired social communication and interaction, average or superior intelligence, and no significant language delay.

Conditions with X-linked dominant inheritance: (Mnemonic - Red Ribbon For All Children)

  • Rickets(Hypophosphatemic)
  • Rett syndrome
  • Fragile X syndrome
  • Alport syndrome
  • Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease

questions.text: A term neonate with Rh incompatibility developed severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The baby was managed with phototherapy and required two cycles of exchange transfusion as well as IVIG. On follow-up presented with recurrent seizures, abnormal hearing screening test and was diagnosed with cerebral palsy at the age of 1 year. MRI revealed evidence of past damage in the bilateral thalami and putamen. Which of the following is the likely type of cerebral palsy suspected in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of basal ganglia injury (involving the thalami and putamen) in the setting of severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, along with seizures and sensorineural hearing loss, is indicative of choreoathetoid cerebral palsy.

Choreoathetoid cerebral palsy:

  • Choreoathetoid cerebral palsy is a form of extrapyramidal CP characterised predominantly by dyskinetic, athetoid movements, especially in the arms, legs, and hands.
  • Athetoid cerebral palsy is often caused by kernicterus due to severe hyperbilirubinemia, secondary to Rh or ABO incompatibility.
  • It can also result from hypoxemic ischemic encephalopathy and other basal ganglia injuries.

Clinical presentations:

  • The affected infant is initially hypotonic, but a tendency toward arching and opisthotonus (dystonia) is noted, and obligatory tonic neck reflexes are present.
  • These primitive motor patterns preclude orderly motor development such as reaching, rolling, and sitting.
  • By 3 years of age, the complete neurologic syndrome is often apparent, which includes:
    • Bilateral choreoathetosis with involuntary muscle spasms
    • Extrapyramidal signs
    • Seizures
    • Mental disability
    • Dysarthric speech, high-­ frequency hearing loss
    • Squinting, defective upward eye movements

Explanation of other options:

Spastic diplegic CP (Option A): Spastic diplegia is characterised by bilateral spasticity of the legs more than the arms, commonly seen in premature infants due to periventricular white matter injury during the vulnerable period of immature oligodendroglia (20-34 weeks' gestation). The first signs often appear when the child begins to crawl. MRI typically shows periventricular leukomalacia.

Spastic quadriplegic CP (Option B): Spastic quadriplegia is the most severe form of cerebral palsy, involving marked spasticity in all four limbs. Common causes include ischemia, infection, metabolic/genetic disorders, and endocrine disorders. MRI may reveal multicystic encephalomalacia, cortical malformations, or periventricular leukomalacia.

Ataxic CP (Option D): Ataxic CP is another form of extrapyramidal CP with predominant ataxic movements. It is the rarest form whose clinical picture is variable, ranging from hypotonia to mild spasticity in addition to incoordination. Ataxic cerebral palsy is caused by traumatic brain damage that occurs during pregnancy or childbirth or later in life via trauma.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child is evaluated for macrocephaly, bulging fontanelles and separation of sutures. Which of the following signs will be unlikely in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical findings in this child are characteristic of hydrocephalus, and papilledema is not typically seen in infants with hydrocephalus.
  • Papilledema indicates sustained raised intracranial pressure; however, in a 6-month-old infant with open, bulging fontanelles, the pressure is dissipated externally through the fontanelles and sutures, so papilledema is typically absent on fundus examination.
  • In older children following suture fusion, features of raised ICP will be seen.

Signs of Hydrocephalus:

  • Sunset Sign/Setting-Sun Sign: Upward gaze palsy due to dilated supraspinal recess pressing on the tectum of the midbrain near the quadrigeminal plate. (Option C ruled out)
  • Mac Ewan's cracked pot sign: Rare/absent in <3 Months of age; crackpot sound on skull percussion suggests sutural separation.
  • Positive transillumination is present due to CSF accumulation, causing massive dilation of the ventricular system. (Option A ruled out)
  • Dilated and prominent scalp veinswill be a physical examination finding due to venous engorgement caused by the enlarged head. (Option D ruled out)

Investigations:

  • Investigation of choice:
    • If sutures open: Transcranial USG
    • If sutures closed: MRI brain
  • X-ray skull - beaten silver appearance

Treatment:

  • Treat the cause
  • Medication to decrease CSF production
    • Acetazolamide: Effective in chronic hydrocephalus associated with increased CSF production
    • Frusemide
  • Surgery
    • Ventriculo-peritoneal shunt: Surgery of choice
    • 3rdVentriculostomy: Endoscopic

questions.text: Which among the following is not an appropriate management in a patient diagnosed with Guillain-Barré syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Guillain-Barré syndrome is an acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) in which steroids are ineffective, whereas chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) responds well to steroid therapy.

Guillain-­ Barré syndrome (GBS) is an autoimmune postinfectious polyneuropathy, characterised by acute onset of ascending, bilaterally symmetrical flaccid weakness.

Treatment:

  • Patients in the early stages of GBS should be admitted to the hospital for observation because the ascending paralysis can rapidly cause respiratory failure and autonomic instability.
  • Patients with milder weakness and slow progression may be treated expectantly, with observation for stabilisation and spontaneous remission.
  • Severe or rapidly progressive muscle weakness is treated with intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG); common protocols include IVIG 0.4 g/kg/day for 5 consecutive days or 1 g/kg/day for 2 days. (Option C ruled out)
  • Plasmapheresis and/ or immunosuppressive drugs are alternatives if IVIG is ineffective. (Option B ruled out)
  • Steroids are not effective for weakness but may help with pain.
  • Supportive care, such as respiratory support, prevention of pressure sores and constipation, nutritional support, pain management, prevention of deep vein thrombosis, and treatment of secondary bacterial infections, is important.
  • Chest physiotherapy is recommended in most patients with GBS, especially those who are admitted to the ICU and receiving ventilation, to reduce the chances of pulmonary impaction & hypostasis pneumonia. (Option D ruled out)
  • Neuropathic pain in GBS should be treated aggressively, with narcotic analgesics where necessary, and with medications such as gabapentin.
  • On the other hand, CIDP can be treated with either oral or pulsed steroids or IVIG, with refractory cases often requiring the use of other immunosuppressive medications.

Key Takeaways:

Treatment of choice in GBS - Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl developed sudden-onset right-sided weakness and numbness of the face, arm, hand, and leg after minor trauma. Symptoms resolved within 25 minutes, and the initial imaging done was normal. Cerebral angiography was performed and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A clinical presentation of TIA with angiogram showing stenosis of the supraclinoid ICA and MCA, giving a puff of smoke appearance, is consistent with Moya Moya Disease.

  • Moyamoya disease (MMD) is an isolated chronic, usually bilateral, vasculopathy of undetermined aetiology.
  • It is characterised by progressive non-atherosclerotic bilateral stenosis of the distal internal carotid arteries and trunks of the anterior and middle cerebral arteries.
  • Vascular inflammation is absent.
  • The lenticulostriate arteries develop a rich collateral circulation predominantly at the base of the brain and around the occlusive lesion, which gives the impression of a puff of smoke (moyamoya in Japanese) on angiography.
  • Other collaterals include transdural anastomoses between the cortical surface branches of the meningeal and scalp arteries.
  • Cerebral ischemic events in the form of TIA or ischemic infarcts are the commonest presentation of all Moyamoya patients.
  • Intracerebral haemorrhage occurs mainly among adult patients with MMD.
  • Seizures can present in both adults and children.

Explanation of other options:

Carotid dissection (Option A): Only a minority of strokes are due to carotid dissection, which often follows minor trauma and presents with facial or neck pain; CT angiography typically shows a characteristic flame-shaped tapering of the carotid artery.

Vasculitis (Option C): Primary CNS vasculitis is confined to the vessels of the central nervous system without evidence of systemic vasculitis. It typically presents with headaches, altered mental status, and focal neurological deficits, and is characterised on angiography by multifocal vessel narrowing or beading, often accompanied by inflammatory changes on MRI.

Fig: Cerebral arteriogram showing dramatic beading (arrow) typical of vasculitis.

Fibromuscular dysplasia (Option D): Fibromuscular dysplasia is a hyperplastic disorder of medium- and small-sized arteries, most often affecting the renal arteries and carotid arteries. It may present with secondary hypertension when the renal arteries are involved, or with transient ischemic attacks or stroke when the carotid or vertebral arteries are affected. On angiography, it is characterised by a string-of-beads appearance.

choices.text: Check shunt patency by nuclear study
Blood culture and take a CSF sample from the shunt tap
Blood culture and take a CSF sample by lumbar puncture

questions.text: A young child with congenital hydrocephalus underwent a ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt procedure. Four months later, the child presents with fever, irritability, and nuchal rigidity. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child has signs of CNS infection (likely shunt-associated meningitis). CSF culture is the gold standard for diagnosis. Since a VP shunt is in place, a shunt tap allows direct sampling of CSF without performing an invasive lumbar puncture.

  • While medical measures may temporarily reduce intracranial pressure, CSF diversion, most commonly by a shunt, is more useful.
  • Ventriculoperitoneal shunt is the surgical treatment of choice for hydrocephalus.
  • It usually requires multiple revisions as the child grows older.

Complications of shunt surgery include:

  • Infection leading to meningitis
  • Sunt displacement
  • Slock or kinking leading to chronic shunt dysfunction
  • Abdominal complications such as peritonitis or abscess.
  • The primary source of shunt-related infection is intraoperative contamination by skin flora.
  • The most common pathogen implicated is coagulase-negative staphylococci, followed by Staphylococcus aureus and Gram-negative bacilli.
  • Treatment of shunt colonisation includes removal of the shunt and systemic antibiotic therapy directed against the isolated organisms.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl with normal development till 6 months is brought to the pediatric OP with complaints of impaired language and communication skills, poor social interaction, breath-holding spells, and repetitive hand-wringing movements. There is also deceleration of head growth noted after 6 months of age. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture suggests a disorder of early brain development characterised by an initial period of normal neonatal growth followed by developmental regression and deceleration of brain growth, findings that are indicative of Rett syndrome.

Rett syndrome:

  • It is an X-linked disease that occurs predominantly in females and is one of the most common causes of cognitive disability in females.
  • Development may proceed normally until 6-12 months of age,when regression of language and motor milestones and acquired microcephaly become apparent.

Key Clinical Features:

  • An ataxic gait or fine tremor of hand movements is an early neurologic finding.
  • Most children develop peculiar sighing respirations with intermittent periods of apnea that may be associated with cyanosis.
  • The hallmark of Rett syndrome is repetitive hand-wringing movementsand a loss of purposeful and spontaneous use of the hands.
  • Autistic behaviour is a typical finding in all patients.
  • Generalised tonic-clonic convulsions occur in the majority and are usually well controlled by anticonvulsants.
  • Feeding disorders and poor weight gain are common.
  • Cardiac arrhythmias may result in sudden, unexpected death at a rate that is higher than the general population.

Treatment:

  • Classic Rett syndrome has been treated with trofinetide, an analogue of the amino-­ terminal tripeptide of insulin-­ like growth factor 1

Explanation of other options:

Asperger syndrome (Option A): Asperger syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder within the family of autism spectrum disorders. It is characterised by impaired social communication and interaction, with a normal or above-average IQ and absence of language delay.

Fragile X-syndrome (Option C): Fragile X syndrome is the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability. It's an X-linked disorder due to CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene.

Conradi syndrome (Option D): Chondrodysplasia punctata (CPD) is a skeletal dysplasia with stippled epiphyses. The X-linked dominant form of CPD, known as Conradi-Hünermann type, presents with ichthyosis and bone changes, while the rhizomelic form features cataracts, facial dysmorphism, proximal limb shortening, and neurodevelopmental delay.

choices.text: Herpes simplex encephalitis has a reasonably good prognosis
Varicella zoster virus encephalitis is predominantly cerebellar
Mumps encephalitis can cause unilateral nerve deafness
Herpes simplex encephalitis predominantly affects the temporal lobe

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding encephalitis are true except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Herpes encephalitis has a very poor prognosis in its full-blown form. Death is common, and in survivors, severe neurological sequelae are common.

HSV encephalitis:

  • Herpes simplex encephalitis is an acute necrotising infection that typically involves the frontal and/or temporal cortex and the limbic system, with selective involvement of the temporal lobes. (Option D ruled out)
  • Injury to the frontal or temporal cortex or limbic system may produce findings more indicative of HSV encephalitis, including anosmia, memory loss, peculiar behaviour, expressive aphasia and other changes in speech, hallucinations, and focal seizures.
  • EEG often shows bitemporal spikes, and MRI or CT imaging reveals abnormalities in the bilateral temporal lobes.
  • HSV has also been associated with autoimmune (NMDA receptor) Encephalitis.
  • The untreated infection progresses to coma and death in 75% of cases.
  • Recovery is usually slow and can take as long as 2 years after symptom onset.

Explanation of other options:

Varicella zoster virus encephalitis is predominantly cerebellar (Option B): Post-infectious encephalitis in varicella infection is cerebellar and presents with ataxia, nystagmus and poor coordination. It is self-correcting and has a good prognosis.

Mumps encephalitis can cause unilateral nerve deafness (Option C): Mumps encephalitis can be associated with sensorineural hearing loss, usually unilateral, but it is rare. Other CNS complications of mumps include transverse myelitis, acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM), aqueductal stenosis, and facial palsy.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was hit on the head by a bouncer while playing cricket, resulting in a concussion. Which of the following symptoms after the injury would warrant further evaluation with neuroimaging?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In a child with a concussion, loss of consciousness is an indication for further evaluation with neuroimaging.
  • Symptoms such as nausea, fatigue, and difficulty falling asleep may persist for weeks to months as part of post-concussion syndrome, but, on their own, do not warrant imaging.

Concussion:

  • Concussion is a form of traumatic brain injury (TBI) caused by sudden acceleration, deceleration, or rotational forces to the brain, which
  • can occur with a blow to the head, neck, face, or body.
  • Concussion typically results in the rapid onset of short-­ lived impairment of neurologic function that resolves spontaneously.
  • Clinical imaging studies (MRI/CT) are typically normal.

Specific symptoms of concussion:

  • Acutely, headache is the most commonly reported symptom, followed by dizziness, difficulty concentrating, and confusion.
  • Sleep disturbance, anxiety, and mood-­ related symptoms are more likely to occur several weeks post-­ injury.
  • Brief loss of consciousness occurs in less than 5% of SRCs and is not associated with injury severity or time to recover.

Pediatric trauma imaging guidelines for head CT:

Head CT is not indicated unless one or more of these criteria are met:

questions.text: Mutation in the SCN1A gene is most commonly associated with which of the following epilepsy syndromes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mutations in the SCN1A gene are the most common cause of Dravet syndrome.

  • Dravet syndromeis the most severe of the phenotypic spectrum of febrile seizure-associated epilepsies.
  • Also known as severe myoclonic epilepsy of infancy, it is initially characterised by febrile and afebrile unilateral clonic seizures that recur every 1 or 2 months.
  • These early seizures are typically induced by fever, but they differ from the usual febrile convulsions in that they are more prolonged, more frequent, and focal and recur in clusters.
  • Seizures subsequently start to occur with lower fevers and then without fever.
  • During the second year of life, myoclonus, atypical absences, and focal seizures occur frequently, and developmental delay usually follows.
  • This syndrome is usually caused by a de novo pathogenic variant, although it is rarely inherited in an autosomal dominant manner or may be inherited from a non-affected carrier parent.
  • Variants in the SCN1A gene are the most common cause of Dravet syndrome (causing ∼80% of all cases).

Explanation of other options:

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (Option A): Lennox-Gastaut syndrome begins between 2-10 years and is characterised by developmental delay, multiple seizure types (including tonic/atonic drop attacks), and an EEG showing 1-2 Hz slow spike-and-wave with polyspike bursts in sleep. Causes include structural brain lesions, hypoxic-ischemic injury, CNS infections, and genetic mutations such as CHD2, STXBP1, and GABRB3.

Rolandic epilepsy (Option B): Benign rolandic epilepsy is the most common benign focal epilepsy of childhood. It typically presents with nocturnal focal seizures, presenting as facial twitching, buccal/throat tingling, drooling, and speech arrest. EEG shows centrotemporal spikes accentuated in sleep. BECTS is most commonly associated with GRIN2A gene mutations, which affect an NMDA receptor subunit.

Otahara syndrome (Option C): Early infantile epileptic encephalopathy presents within the first 2 months of life, characterised by a burst-suppression pattern on EEG and tonic seizures. It is caused by brain malformations or epileptogenic gene mutations. The most common gene implicated is STXBP1.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child continues to move using a commando crawl. This finding is most suggestive of which condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Commando crawling is a characteristic finding in the spastic diplegia variant of cerebral palsy.

Spastic diplegia:

  • Spastic diplegia is bilateral spasticity of the legs that is greater than in the arms.
  • There is a strong association with injury to the immature white matter during the vulnerable period of immature oligodendroglia between 20 and 34 weeks of gestation, hence seen in those born prematurely.
  • Examination of the child reveals symmetric spasticity in the legs with brisk reflexes, ankle clonus, and a bilateral Babinski sign.

Signs in Spastic Diplegic Cerebral Palsy

  • Scissoring of gait: When the child is suspended by the axillae, an extended scissoring posture of the lower extremities is maintained.
  • Commando Crawl: The child uses the arms in a normal reciprocal fashion but tends to drag the legs behind more as a rudder rather than using the normal four-­ limbed crawling movement.
  • Fisting of hands- The child usually keeps both fists tightly closed.
  • Walking can be significantly delayed, the feet are held in a position of equinovarus, and the child walks on tiptoes.

Explanation of other options:

Normal variant (Option A): Commando crawling is normal in infants around 6-9 months of age. By 1 year of age, normal motor development includes pulling to stand, cruising, or walking with support; persistence of commando crawling beyond 9 months is abnormal and suggests an underlying motor disorder such as spastic diplegia.

Spastic quadriplegia (Option C): Spastic quadriplegia is the most severe form of CP because of marked motor impairment of all extremities with global developmental delay. Neurologic examination shows increased tone and spasticity in all extremities, decreased spontaneous movements, brisk reflexes, and plantar extensor responses.

Proximal myopathy (Option D): In proximal myopathy, patients present with difficulty climbing stairs, rising from sitting, or lifting the arms above the head. Additional signs include waddling gait, lumbar lordosis, and occasionally Gowers' sign.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child with previously normal development presents with progressive loss of language skills, verbal auditory agnosia, and multiple seizure types. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Landau-Kleffner syndrome

  • It is a rare condition of presumed autoimmune but sometimes also of genetic (GRIN2A mutations)
  • It is characterised by loss of language skills and by verbal auditory agnosia in a previously normal child.
  • At least 70% have associated clinical seizures, but some do not. The seizures, when they occur, are of several types, including focal with preserved awareness, focal to bilateral tonic-clonic, atypical absence, focal with impaired awareness, and occasionallymyoclonic seizures.
  • High-amplitude spike-and-wave discharges predominate and tend to be bitemporal.
  • CT and MRI studies typically yield normal results.
  • Valproic acidis often the anticonvulsant that is used first to treat clinical seizures and may help the aphasia.
  • Some children respond to clobazam, to the combination ofvalproic acid and clobazam, or to levetiracetam. Prednisolone may also be effective.

Explanation of other options:

Neuronal Ceroid Lipofuscinosis (Option B): The neuronal ceroid lipofuscinoses (NCLs) are a group of inherited, neurodegenerative, lysosomal storage disorders characterised by visual loss, progressive dementia, seizures, motor deterioration, and early death. Language regression occurs along with other systemic neurodegenerative features, but not as isolated verbal auditory agnosia.

Rett Syndrome (Option C): Rett syndrome is an X-linked disorder in which development is normal until 6-12 months of age, after which there is regression of language and motor milestones along with the development of acquired microcephaly. The hallmark feature is repetitive hand-wringing movements with loss of purposeful and spontaneous hand use.

Asperger syndrome (Option D): Asperger syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder within the family of autism spectrum disorders. It is characterised by impaired social communication and interaction, with a normal or above-average IQ and absence of language delay. In Asperger syndrome, there is no developmental regression after 3 years of age.

questions.text: A child with a 2-week history of fever, poor feeding, and irritability was examined and found to have neck rigidity. CSF obtained via lumbar puncture is shown in the image below. Which of the following CSF findings is most likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above image shows CSF with a cobweb-like clot, which, along with the clinical presentation, is indicative of tuberculous meningitis - characterised by lymphocytic predominance, low glucose, and high protein levels.

Tubercular meningitis:

  • Usually occurs secondary to a primary focus (e.g., pulmonary, gastrointestinal) with hematogenous spread leading to a Rich focus (meningeal lesion) and subsequent spread to the CSF.
  • Compared to pyogenic meningitis, tuberculous meningitis has a longer prodromal phase of 1-4 weeks and a more subacute course, often with a history of contact with tuberculosis.

Clinical features:

  • The first or prodromal phase of the illness, which lasts 1-4 weeks, is characterised by nonspecific irregular fever, anorexia, irritability and occasional vomiting.
  • Stage 2 has neurological manifestations like seizures, focal deficits and meningeal signs.
  • Stage 3 is one of coma and sequelae.
  • Hydrocephalus (communicating or obstructive), decerebrate posturing, cranial nerve palsies, optic atrophy, extrapyramidal signs, and focal deficits are more common in tuberculous than other CNS infections.

Diagnosis:

  • CSF findings:
    • Elevated opening pressure
    • Lymphocytic predominance with up to 500 cells per mm'
    • Increased protein levels
    • Low sugar level (about half the concomitant blood sugar level)
    • Low CSF chloride level and elevated ADA levels
    • If CSF is left to stand still, a fine clot resembling a pellicle or cobweb may form

Neuroimaging often shows hydrocephalus and basal exudates with signs of cerebral oedema or early focal ischemia.

Culture is the gold standard for diagnosing tuberculous meningitis. PCR testing of CSF and measurement of ADA levels can support the diagnosis, while the detection of acid-fast bacilli in the CSF confirms it definitively.

Treatment:

Anti-tubercular therapy for a total duration of 9-12 months (intensive phase of 3 months followed by a consolidation phase of 6-9 months), along with dexamethasone (low dose daily for 8-12 weeks) due to higher risk of inflammation.

questions.text: A 9-month-old female child is evaluated following a history of febrile seizures, which occurred when her rectal temperature was 38-39 °C. The interval between fever onset and seizure was more than 24 hours. There is no family history or complex features, and blood investigations were normal. What is the approximate risk of recurrence with each febrile illness in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child has one major risk factor for recurrence of febrile seizure, which is a temperature of 38-39 °C, and has no minor risk factors. The presence of a single risk factor confers a risk of 25-50% while no risk factors confers a recurrence risk of 12%.

Risk factors for recurrence of febrile seizures.

Major:

  • Age < 1 year
  • Duration of fever < 24 hr
  • Fever 38-39°C (100.4 - 102°F)

Minor:

  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Family history of epilepsy
  • Complex febrile seizure
  • Daycare
  • Male gender
  • Low serum sodium at the time of presentation

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents with fever for 3 days, vomiting, photophobia, neck stiffness, and papilledema. Before initiating therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate initial investigation for this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child has features suggestive of meningitis, and neuroimaging should precede lumbar puncture when there is suspicion of raised intracranial pressure, such as papilledema. Contrast-enhanced CT Scan (CECT) is usually preferred in such cases.

  • In suspected meningitis, lumbar puncture (LP) with CSF analysis is the standard investigation of choice. However, this child has papilledema, which strongly suggests raised intracranial pressure (ICP).
  • Performing LP in the presence of raised ICP is an absolute contraindication because it may precipitate cerebral herniation. (Option A ruled out)
  • Before LP, neuroimaging should be performed to assess for space-occupying lesions, obstructive hydrocephalus, or significant cerebral oedema.
  • CECT is not highly sensitive for diagnosing meningitis itself. However, CECT head is preferred in this setting as it:
    • Rapidly detects features of raised ICP (e.g., dilated ventricles, midline shift).
    • Can show meningeal enhancement suggestive of meningitis
    • Faster and more widely available modality than MRI in emergencies.

Explanation of other options:

Transcranial USG (Option B): In a 3-year-old, the anterior fontanelle is already closed, limiting ultrasound penetration and image quality. As a result, its sensitivity for detecting raised ICP or intracranial pathology is poor, making it unsuitable in this scenario.

MRI Brain (Option D): MRI with contrast is the most sensitive for meningitis. It provides a more detailed view of the anatomy without exposing the patient to ionising radiation. But it is time-consuming and can only be done in a stable patient, not in someone with acutely elevated ICP.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child was diagnosed with pyogenic meningitis on 1st January 2024. Intravenous ceftriaxone therapy was initiated on the same day at 9:00 AM, and the child was placed in isolation. After how long can the child be considered non-infectious and safely removed from isolation precautions?
A 3-year-old child was diagnosed with pyogenic meningitis on 1st January 2024. He was started on IV Ceftriaxone on the same day at 9 AM after admission and was isolated. After how long will it be considered non-infectious and can come out of isolation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Any child with pyogenic meningitis, once started on intravenous third-generation cephalosporins, becomes non-infectious and achieves sterile CSF within 24 hours of antibiotic initiation.
  • In this case, since treatment began at 9:00 AM on 1st January 2024, isolation can be discontinued from 9:00 AM on 2nd January 2024 onwards.

Bacterial meningitis:

  • Most bacterial meningitis is caused by S. pneumoniae and N. meningitidis, whereas H. influenzae type b is relatively rare in nations with high immunisation rates.
  • Lumbar puncture (LP), to obtain CSF for Gram stain and culture, is the most important step in the diagnosis of meningitis.
  • Testing of the CSF for neutrophilic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and/or reduced glucose concentrations can yield results within a few hours and can indicate bacterial meningitis.

Antibiotic treatment in bacterial meningitis:

  • The recommended empiric antibiotic regimen in suspected bacterial meningitis beyond the neonatal period is a third-­ generation cephalosporin (ceftriaxone) plus vancomycin.
  • Because of the efficacy of third-­ generation cephalosporins in the therapy of meningitis caused by sensitive S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, and H. influenzae type b, ceftriaxone (50 mg/kg/dose given every 12 hours) should be part of initial therapy.
  • Based on the current incidence of cephalosporin-­ resistant strains of S. pneumoniae, vancomycin is also recommended as part of empiric therapy.
  • Patients allergic to penicillin and cephalosporin antibiotics can be treated with meropenem; other alternatives include fluoroquinolones or chloramphenicol, if available.
  • The CSF in most cases will be sterile within 24-­ 48 hours of initiation of appropriate antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A young child has been diagnosed with Haemophilus influenzae meningitis. At follow-up, which of the following investigations is most appropriate to assess for a common complication associated with this infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

H influenzae-associated meningitis is commonly associated with the risk of developing sensorineural hearing loss; therefore, all these children need to be evaluated by the BERA test for hearing at discharge and follow-up.

  • In the pre-vaccine era, meningitis accounted for more than half of all cases of invasive H. influenzae disease.
  • Major neurologic sequelae of Hib meningitis include behaviour problems, language disorders, impaired vision, mental retardation, motor abnormalities, ataxia, seizures, and hydrocephalus.
  • Approximately 6% of patients with Hib meningitis are left with some hearing impairment, probably because of inflammation of the cochlea and the labyrinth.
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b, once the most common cause of meningitis resulting in SNHL, is rare owing to the H. influenzae type b conjugate vaccine.
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis that results in SNHL after the neonatal period and has become less common with the routine administration of pneumococcal conjugate vaccine.
  • When these infectious etiologies occur, the resulting hearing loss is frequently bilateral and severe.

Explanation of other options:

CBC (Option A): A complete blood count can only be used for evaluation during the acute phase to monitor infection and response to antibiotics.

CECT head (Option B): Contrast-enhanced CT is used to highlight areas of breakdown in the blood-­ brain barrier (e.g., abscesses, tumours) and/or collections of abnormal blood vessels (e.g., arteriovenous malformations).

MRI brain (Option C): MRI is used to evaluate for congenital or acquired brain lesions, migrational defects, dysmyelination or demyelination, post-traumatic gliosis, neoplasms, cerebral oedema, and acute stroke
